Situation1: A minor misunderstanding about weekend plans just arose.
Expectation2: Deliver packages on time and to the correct address
Situation2: A customer urgently needs their delivery by the promised time window, such as groceries for dinner
Story:
I glanced at my phone, heart pounding. My girlfriend’s text glared at me: “I thought we agreed on Saturday, not Sunday. Why don’t you ever listen?” I could almost hear the frustration in her words. As her boyfriend, I knew I should call her, talk it out, and clear up the misunderstanding before it grew into something bigger. She expected me to be present, to resolve things quickly, to show I cared.

But the delivery app pinged again, reminding me of the groceries in my trunk and the customer waiting at the next stop. The order was marked “urgent”—they needed everything for dinner, and the time window was closing fast. As a delivery person, I was expected to be reliable, to get packages to the right place on time, no excuses.

I sat in my car, torn. If I called my girlfriend now, I’d risk being late and disappointing a customer who was counting on me. If I kept driving, I’d leave her feeling ignored and uncared for. My hands tightened on the steering wheel, caught between two worlds, both demanding more than I could give at once.
